comments.commentBody: I part company with Mr. Kristof on the Bergdahl "trade" but on the whole I agree that the President has done reasonably well with his foreign policy decisions- considering that in one situation after another there have been no surefire decisions to be made.  Americans don't want to keep sending their children to fight and die over situations that don't seem to concern us, and without his having this option to rely upon (and without having the chutzpah to dissemble about the reasons for sending them to foreign battlefields) the President is compelled to make do with the option of diplomacy.  Unhappily, this latter alternative doesn't work so well with unelected dictators and oligarchs who have no reason to care what their subjects think- let alone the rest of the world.  Americans would likely be very happy with the President's policy were it actually bearing fruit.  On the other hand, if you're not going to use American military power (i.e., the lives of our children) to help resolve an obscure point of disagreement vis a vis the line of Muslim leadership following the death of the Prophet (!!) it's senseless to intervene in such arguments in the first place.

'so the President lost his power to nominate? That is what happened here.'

- only if you have the funny illusion that Europe has 'one' President!

So, Obama called Merkel up yesterday and promised her a back rub if she is good later today.

Also, he promised to send more thousands more GI's. "That way we can both get a full complement of 22 athletic players for our teams by 2034", he reasoned.
Anything that involves putting an instrument, such as a needle, into the body would be considered invasive.

We've spent decades with a large military presence in Japan and Germany for some reason, and Korea. Anyone who thought we could fight for a decade in Afghanistan and Iraq and then walk away was naive. Never should have been there to begin with. Iraq may well be the our downfall similar to the old Soviet Union. Bin Laden and Al Queda in Afghanistan could have been dealt with using special ops. Same way we got him finally in Pakistan.

Western militaries became unbeatable during WWII. We knew who the enemy was. They wore uniforms displaying where they were from. We haven't been able to tell the good guys from the bad guys since Vietnam. The NRA seems to think they know who the good guys are but they keep getting it wrong too.

The comments by JRMW are spot-on. Mr Kerry and Mr Obama are spouting a foreign policy about Iraq which is totally impossible at this point-if it ever was valid. The US basically has no friends in the Islamic world and to hang on to the Shia government in Baghdad will prove to be the final arrow. Rather than mount a ridiculous "adviser" group in Baghdad-which will do nothing-the US should fold their tents in Iraq-stop making comments about unity government-and accept reality. Reality is that the whole Iraq invasion fiasco has contributed to the current factional war-and it is a religious war by any measure. I think the bottom line now for US policy is get out of Iraq. What is there to be gained by propping up Maliki or any other Shia government? Why is so hard for Americans to admit that the invasions of both Iraq and Afghanistan were gross mistakes in judgement. Of course, history will make that decision. I would hate to be the person who would have to tell wounded US veterans that "well, it was all a mistake" Someone in the future will have to make that assessment.

Maliki has been contemptuous of the United States at every point and is, by all accounts, in league with Iran, a country that is supposed to be our mortal enemy. So we are sending advisors and equipment to prop him up? Why?

The U.S. has proved it will happily purchase oil from any dictatorship, so what is the concern here? Pres. Obama needs to explain what, exactly, is at stake here because I am trying to find out who the 'good guys' are in this fiasco, and I cannot find them on any side.

Back in 2008, candidate Joe Biden stated he thought that Iraq might be better off divided into three autonomous regions according to tribal affiliations. It looks like that is what is happening after all and with no 'help' from us.
Iran shares a large border with Iraq... if there were similar battles occurring in Canada or Mexico, the US would be deeply involved in a heartbeat.

SI, DEB, had I found a ROACH [in] BED, I would have SCREAMED, for sure.

Even better (bedder? Sheesh, now I'm doing it too), column 7 gives us a semi-cryptic Rebbits[in] DEB...no BED

Gee, something the fab five could understand. I guess even they have cell phones. Maybe there wasn't a clear way for corporations to profit? After all, it only affects the police, those nasty, incompetent government employees.

When curious about which party is willing to let the individual live an un-examined life free of snooping, the 1st clue is who wants government doing more and more things and needs ore power and money to do them, -

versus which party is all about shrinking the federal level back to the original Founders' intent because they knew the higher the position, the more damage the wrong person in that position could do through theft, partisanship, or disloyalty.

The people who would form the Soviet Union also started out rebelling at structures of the previous arrangement, only to make 400 million people into prisoners subjected to the most cruel existence imaginable.

To transform a country, you will spend most of your energy destroying anything that made that country last as long as it did, and as successful as it was. We till have churches and the ability to travel, which a hardened cynic would suggest that Mr. Obama regrets that he won't be able to get to dealing with.

It seems to me that as a result of this decision, the NSA would then need a warrant to track cell phone calls.  It furthermore seems that online calling apps, such as Skype, would also fall under this decision: a warrant is needed before the account information is passed over to authorities.

You notice that people always use "ilk" with a negative connotation, although it's not necessarily the meaning?  I think the NSA does a lot of great things for us and I just can't use a word like that for them. But, I do agree with you that there is a good chance they are doing more than they say, at least on occasion. How many times have we seen - the government runs with the ball until someone tackles them?  I am pretty sure, whoever is next elected president, Democrat or Republican will not change that (not even Rand Paul, once he is saddled with the responsibility) and we will learn what really happened in a decade or two or three.

Phone companies have call and text records that may be examined later - with a warrant.  There's no need to rely on responding cops to review a phone (and all the private information that it might hold) at the scene of the accident.  There is lots of room for error, and they have enough to deal with getting witness statements and gathering other evidence.  I totally understand where you're coming from, but these things can be sorted out after the fact. This is a good decision.
Wait. Wait. Wait. Wait for this. Thomas voted Yay for this?

I agree 100%, but the test is to come.

There will be a case where a phone is not searched, contains a hit list in a text to a group and shortly after arrest the next person on the list is murdered. The hit list would have been seen immediately if the cops had searched the phone and the murder prevented.

At that point we, as a society, have to have the fortitude to accept that the murdered person's life did not outweigh our need for privacy. This won't be easy. In general our bill of rights freedoms are enjoyed by all but paid for by random, miscellaneous citizens that are in the wrong place at the wrong time.
A different idea. Collecting DNA at the time of an arrest is like taking and checking for finger prints.
Funny that the Court would require a warrant to search a phone but not to collect one's DNA.

I don't believe that for one second, because the government isn't that capable or competent. "WMD's" anyone? "Mission Accomplished?" "The economy will be fine." "The recession is over." "Because of the bad weather." And, how about that farce with the Boston Marathon bombers - no obvious warning signs in advance of that, eh?

Keep believing that government propaganda about it only being "metadata".

Meanwhile, emails, social networks, texts, chat sessions, GPS coordinates, phone calls (audio) and Internet browsing will continue to be monitored. All exposed by Snowden.

They would need probable cause or exigent circumstances. Any other use (even using a cell phone to identify a victim) would be a tort and thus actionable (unless the state has removed itself from that specific tort claim, which is very likely). But more importantly, as fruit of the poisonous tree they wouldn't be able to use any information they found on that phone unless they get a warrant, and wouldn't be able to use the information found on the phone as evidence of probable cause to obtain the warrant.

But not at the expense of our right to privacy. You know. The one that give women the right to an abortion? In a simpler example, would we allow the police to kick in our doors to search for evidence with a warrant? Other than the IRS which can search through your credit card receipts, bank deposits and written checks fishing for crimes committed we are pretty safe from government intrusion, aren't we?

I believe this ruling is a blow to law enforcement, because during a routine traffic stop, for example, the officer could examine the contents of the person's cell phone and discover if the individual had committed other crimes.  Texts to drug dealers for instance could be discovered.  Texts and calls to pimps, terrorists, traffickers, all could be discovered.  This would, of course, lead to the law breaking individual thrown behind bars, where he/she belongs, and then begin an investigation to catch the other criminals.  By the time law enforcement is done checking all the cell phones, all the criminals will be gathered up and the United States will become once again a law bidding land.  Think about, a land of law bidding citizens, no drugs, no pimps, no terrorists, no traffickers.  Oh what wonderful place it would be!

A gun is a gun is a gun. 1 piece of physical equipment. Same now as 250 years ago. Meanwhile what it said about paper and effects are no longer confined to a stationary physical item. You can carry more on your phone now than all of the world's libraries back then.

That's the difference.
Yup.. why should 99% of the public be treated like criminals, because of 1% of the population?
the media does a pretty good job of getting the word out, we dont need cops for that little scenario.
Amen, Kuchenstück...

and what really 'happened' here is a bit what happens in the American Congress - Crazy Men and women who get elected by crazy men and women to be crazy -(aka: 'Destroy every idea of unity) - try to destry every idea of unity!
